Art</p>=0D=0A</td>=0D=0A<td>&=\r\nnbsp;</td>=0D=0A</tr>=0D=0A</tbody>=0D=0A</table></div></div></td></tr><tr =\r\nclass=3D\"r3\" id=3D\"r3_22239\"><td colspan=3D\"2\" rowspan=3D\"1\"  width=3D\"680\"=\r\n  id=3D\"c_394295\" ><table class=3D\"shaded\"><tr><td><h3 style=3D\"text-align:=\r\n left;\">=0D=0A<p><a title=3D\"english\" name=3D\"english\"></a>ENGLISH</p>=0D=\r\n=0A</h3>=0D=0A<p>The English program at The Beekman School concentrates on =\r\nthe development of four integral skills, which are essential for succeeding=\r\n across the curriculum:&nbsp; reading, written communication, oral communic=\r\nation, and critical thinking.&nbsp;Students are required to actively partic=\r\nipate in lessons through group work, seminar discussions, in-class writing,=\r\n and note taking during lectures.&nbsp;At the start of each semester, teach=\r\ners will provide the rules regarding homework, absences, deadlines and othe=\r\nr information for that particular class.</p>=0D=0A<blockquote>=0D=0A<p><str=\r\nong>ENGLISH I</strong> <br />In this class, students are introduced to vari=\r\nous literary genres such as drama, the short story, the novel, poetry, and =\r\nnon-fiction.&nbsp;Students come to The Beekman School with a diverse readin=\r\ng background therefore our reading list varies, but a sampling may include:=\r\n&nbsp; <em>Romeo and Juliet</em>,&nbsp;<em>Siddhartha, Lord of The Flies, T=\r\nhe Old Man and The Sea, A Doll's House, To Kill a Mockingbird</em>, as well=\r\n as selections of poetry, non-fiction, and short stories.</p>=0D=0A<p>Essay=\r\ns and papers tend to be based on literature to encourage students to think =\r\ncritically and to develop a solid, accurate, expressive writing style.&nbsp=\r\n;Creative and personal writing assignments will be given throughout the yea=\r\nr to help continue the development of each writer's personal \"voice\" and st=\r\nyle.&nbsp;During the second semester, students will write a research paper,=\r\n using three to five outside sources.</p>=0D=0A<p>Vocabulary words are gath=\r\nered from the literature and the SAT word list.&nbsp;Grammar lessons and qu=\r\nizzes cover topics such as apostrophes, pronouns, subject/verb agreement, a=\r\nnd commas.&nbsp;Students are also expected to develop proofreading skills t=\r\no improve the grammar in their written work.</p>=0D=0A</blockquote>=0D=0A<b=\r\nlockquote>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: x=\r\nx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\">back to top<=\r\n/a> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A</blockquote>=0D=0A<blockquote>=0D=0A<p>=\r\n<strong>ENGLISH II</strong> <br />This course seeks to further build on the=\r\n introduction offered in English I.&nbsp;In addition to reviews of the genr=\r\nes, attention is focused on the nuances of figurative language and structur=\r\ne in a given work.&nbsp;Students will learn to identify how formal choices =\r\nin literature enhance theme.&nbsp;In addition, concepts such as satire, iro=\r\nny, abstraction, tragedy, romanticism, and realism will be studied, using w=\r\norks from various literary periods.&nbsp;Students come to The Beekman Schoo=\r\nl with a diverse reading background, our reading list varies, but a samplin=\r\ng may include:&nbsp;<em>Nine Stories, The Chosen, The Grapes of Wrath, Cat'=\r\ns Cradle, Oedipus Rex</em>, as well as selections of poetry, non-fiction, a=\r\nnd short stories.</p>=0D=0A<p>The writing assignments will be of greater le=\r\nngth and complexity than in English I.&nbsp;The expansion of critical and a=\r\nnalytical skills will be put to use in exposition, persuasion, poetry, narr=\r\nation, and personal writing.&nbsp;There will also be creative and personal =\r\nwriting assignments given to help continue the development of each writer's=\r\n personal \"voice\" and style.&nbsp;During the second semester, students will=\r\n write a research paper, using three to five outside sources.</p>=0D=0A<p>V=\r\nocabulary words are gathered from the literature and the SAT word list.&nbs=\r\np;Grammar lessons and quizzes cover topics such as apostrophes, pronouns, s=\r\nubject/verb agreement, and commas.&nbsp;Students are also expected to devel=\r\nop proofreading skills to improve the grammar in their written work.</p>=0D=\r\n=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><e=\r\nm><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></=\r\nstrong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </f=\r\nont></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>ENGLISH III<br /></strong>The primar=\r\ny focus of this class will be American literature <em>before </em>the 20<su=\r\np>th</sup> century. However, we also examine texts from outside America, in=\r\ncluding Shakespeare, English poetry, and, time permitting, various other wr=\r\niters in whom students express interest.The American texts covered may incl=\r\nude names with which you are probably familiar: Nathaniel Hawthorne, Henry =\r\nThoreau, Herman Melville, Mark Twain, Stephen Crane, Emily Dickinson, and o=\r\nthers. We also read lesser known authors such as Charlotte Gilman, Elizabet=\r\nh Stuart Phelps, Harriett Beecher Stowe, and Susan Glaspell because their w=\r\norks tell us much about the issues of the day, from women's rights to relig=\r\nious freedom to attitudes towards war and capitalism.</p>=0D=0A<p>This clas=\r\ns will demand writing assignments of greater length and complexity than in =\r\nprevious classes. At this point attention to detail, proof reading, line ed=\r\niting and final revisions are mandatory.&nbsp;The work completed in this cl=\r\nass is focused on preparing students for their senior year and beyond.&nbsp=\r\n;During the second semester, students will write a research paper on a subj=\r\nect of their own choosing, using at least six outside sources.</p>=0D=0A<p>=\r\nVocabulary words are gathered from the literature and the SAT word list.&nb=\r\nsp;Grammar lessons and quizzes cover topics such as apostrophes, pronouns, =\r\nsubject/verb agreement, and commas.&nbsp;Students are also expected to deve=\r\nlop proofreading skills to improve the grammar in their written work.</p>=\r\n=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong=\r\n><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em=\r\n></strong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> =\r\n</font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>ENGLISH IV<br /></strong>The prim=\r\nary focus of this class will is American literature ofthe 20<sup>th</sup> c=\r\nentury. However, we also will be examining texts from outside America, incl=\r\nuding Shakespeare, English poetry, and, time permitting, various other writ=\r\ners in whom students express interest.The American texts will be covered th=\r\nematically. For example, we may cover works by authors who write about the =\r\nAmerican West, such as Willa Cather's <em>Death Comes for the Archbishop</e=\r\nm> or Sanora Babb's recently discovered novel about westward migration duri=\r\nng the Depression, <em>Whose Names Are Unknown</em>. Another thematic unit =\r\nmay include an examination of individual freedom, when we'll read Herman Me=\r\nlville's \"Bartleby, the Scrivner,\" T.S. Eliot's \"The Love Song of J. Alfred=\r\n Prufrock, and Jon Krakauer's<em>Into the Wild</em>. We'll also study the A=\r\nmerican struggle with race, sampling from writers such as Flannery O'Connor=\r\n, James Weldon Johnson, and John Howard Griffin, author of <em>Black Like M=\r\ne. </em></p>=0D=0A<p>This class will demand writing assignments of greater =\r\nlength and complexity than in previous semesters.&nbsp;It is at this point =\r\nthat attention to detail, proof reading, line editing and final revisions a=\r\nre mandatory.&nbsp;The work completed in this class is focused on preparing=\r\n students for their senior year and beyond.&nbsp; s always, there will be c=\r\nreative and personal writing assignments.&nbsp;In the second semester, stud=\r\nents engage in a research project.&nbsp;This project culminates in a synthe=\r\nsis of several sources (minimum eight) into a paper, which is a unique crea=\r\ntion of the student.</p>=0D=0A<p>Vocabulary words are gathered from the lit=\r\nerature and the SAT word list.&nbsp;Grammar lessons and quizzes cover topic=\r\ns such as apostrophes, pronouns, subject/verb agreement, and commas.&nbsp;S=\r\ntudents are also expected to develop proofreading skills to improve the gra=\r\nmmar in their written work.</p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pagevi=\r\new.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" si=\r\nze=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"fon=\r\nt-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>AD=\r\nVANCED ENGLISH</strong> <br />This class is an \"invitation only\" course. St=\r\nudents must be recommended by a teacher in order to join this course. It is=\r\n assumed that any student in this class can easily write a standard 5-parag=\r\nraph essay and has completed at least 2 lengthy research papers in previous=\r\n English courses. The workload can be great; work is usually assigned seven=\r\n days a week and over both winter and spring vacations. Students who do not=\r\n perform up to class standards may be transferred into an easier, yet still=\r\n high-level English IV course.</p>=0D=0A<p>The Advanced English course fost=\r\ners excellence in independent reading and writing, class participation, and=\r\n creativity. The texts and writing assignments are at a reading and content=\r\n level commensurate with college classes. Students will be challenged by ex=\r\npository and analytical writing assignments, and are expected to challenge =\r\nthemselves in their informal reading logs throughout the year.</p>=0D=0A<sp=\r\nan id=3D\"xg_318\">=0D=0A<p>Our reading covers a wide cultural swath. Literat=\r\nure may include <em>The Assault</em> by Harry Mulisch (Holland), <em>Maze o=\r\nf Justice: Diary of a Country Prosecutor&nbsp; </em>byTawfik al-Hakim (Egyp=\r\nt), <em>Wine and Astonishment </em>by Earl Lovelace (Trinidad),<em> Exile a=\r\nnd the Kingdom </em>by Albert Camus (France), <em>As I Lay Dying</em> by Wi=\r\nlliam Faulkner (U.S.), and <em>The Power and the Glory</em> by Graham Green=\r\ne (British), as well as Shakespeare and Chaucer's <em>Canterbury Tales</em>=\r\n. We will &nbsp;studypoetry, with an emphasis on David Jones' World War I e=\r\npic <em>In Parenthesis</em>.&nbsp; Other possible readings will depend on s=\r\ntudent interest.</p>=0D=0A</span>=0D=0A<p><em>Writing</em><br />Lengthy ess=\r\nays are not usually required. It is much more difficult to analyze material=\r\n and present it in a succinct, well-written short essay. Essays vary in len=\r\ngth from 3 to 5 pages. All essays must be typed, double-spaced. Writing ass=\r\nignments are unique and varied. Some assignments incorporate art and music,=\r\n some are creative in nature, most are analytical&mdash;whether its require=\r\nd length is a paragraph or a page. Students are not graded competitively, t=\r\nhus there is no curve. It is possible for all students to earn A's or for a=\r\nll students to fail.</p>=0D=0A<p><em>Vocabulary and Grammar</em><br />Vocab=\r\nulary words are gathered from the literature. Grammar lessons are drawn fro=\r\nm student errors made during the course of an assignment. Students will rev=\r\niew the more complex issues of grammar and examine why certain obscure gram=\r\nmatical rules exist.</p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx=\r\n?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1=\r\n\">back to top</font></em></strong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size:=\r\n xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>CREATIVE =\r\nWRITING<br /></strong>The primary focus of this course is to generate origi=\r\nnal writing in fiction and poetry. Students will discover their personal vo=\r\nice and style through a variety of writing assignments. During the first qu=\r\narter, students will focus on fiction writing and will learn about differen=\r\nt craft choices in terms of point of view, setting, character, conflict, di=\r\nalogue, and revision through a series of daily, shorter writing assignments=\r\n as well as longer short-story projects. During the second quarter, student=\r\ns will be asked to turn their attention to poetry. In this quarter, student=\r\ns will study a variety of poetic forms and will try these forms out in thei=\r\nr own poetry. Cooperative skills will be honed during Workshops where stude=\r\nnts will read each other's work, engage in discussion, and offer suggestion=\r\ns for revision. Additionally, as writers learn to become better writers by =\r\nreading, this class will also look at several exemplary short stories and p=\r\noems to examine craft choices from a writer's perspective. Creativity will =\r\nbe promoted in an environment of mutual acceptance.&nbsp;</p>=0D=0A</blockq=\r\nuote>=0D=0A<blockquote>=0D=0A<p>The Beekman School Literary &amp; Arts Jour=\r\nnal is produced every Spring semester.&nbsp; It is a student-generated proj=\r\nect, completed in-house, with the full participation of every student in th=\r\ne class.&nbsp; While students in the Fall semester will not be participatin=\r\ng in the actual production of the journal, their work will be represented i=\r\nn the journal. Students in either the Fall or Spring semester class are req=\r\nuired to submit work as part of their participation grade.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT=\r\n: Course materials will be drawn from various sources.</p>=0D=0A<p align=3D=\r\n\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=\r\n=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a><s=\r\ntrong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></st=\r\nrong></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>EASTERN PHILOSOPHY</strong><br />This is a one-se=\r\nmester introduction to Eastern thought, both historical and current. The fi=\r\nrst quarter begins with readings of selected works by Lao Tzu (chapters of =\r\nthe Tao Te Ching in various translations) and the poetry of Chaung Tzu, as =\r\nphilosophical Taoism is studied. This is followed by an investigation of Co=\r\nnfucianism, which is studied in its own right, and is then compared to and =\r\ncontrasted with Taoism. In whatever time remains in the 1st Quarter, Hindui=\r\nsm is then surveyed, with special attention given to the Vedas, Vedanta, an=\r\nd the person of Shankara. The non-dualism of some of the Hindu schools is d=\r\niscussed and explored.</p>=0D=0A<p>The second quarter undertakes a study of=\r\n Buddhism, beginning with a study of the life and teachings of Siddhartha G=\r\nautama, the historical Buddha. Following the death of Buddha, we examine th=\r\ne history and underlying philosophies of the various branches that develope=\r\nd inside Buddhism: Theravada, Mahayana, and eventually Vajrayana. Zen Buddh=\r\nism is then focused on, both as a particular offshoot of Mahayana Buddhism =\r\nin its canonical history, but also as the philosophical hybrid of both Indi=\r\nan Buddhism and Chinese Taoism.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: The Religions of Man, by =\r\nHuston Smith.</p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D2=\r\n2239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back =\r\nto top</font></em></strong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-sma=\r\nll;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>WESTERN PHILOSOP=\r\nHY<br /></strong>This is a one-semester course that will provide a general =\r\noverview of the most predominant philosophers of Western Civilization. Phil=\r\nosophers studied: Socrates, Plato and Aristotle; the course then moves into=\r\n the era of more modern philosophers. Some of the modern philosophers studi=\r\ned may include: Thomas Aquinas, Descartes, Kant, Hume, Rousseau, Wollstonec=\r\nraft, Hegel, Hobbes, Locke, Nietzsche, and Kiergegaard. Finally, the course=\r\n ends with the examination of the major Existentialists: Sartre and Camus.<=\r\n/p>=0D=0A<p>Issues to be studied can include: Examining the idea of a unive=\r\nrsal right / wrong, systems of reality, reality of the self vs. reality of =\r\nthe society, ethics, morality, justice, religion, human freedom, philosophi=\r\ncal questions of epistemology, skepticism, truth, aesthetics, the role of t=\r\nhe senses, existentialism, deconstruction, and post-modernism.</p>=0D=0A<p>=\r\nTEXT: From Plato to Derrida, 4th Edition, Baird, F., Kaufman, W. Prentice H=\r\nall, 2003 <br />Alternate Text: From Socrates to Sartre: A Philosophical Qu=\r\nest, Levin, T.Z.</p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=\r\n=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">b=\r\nack to top</font></em></strong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx=\r\n-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>SCIENCE FICT=\r\nION LITERATURE</strong> <br />Norman Mailer recently wrote in The New Yorke=\r\nr, &ldquo;Realism is not a direct approach to the truth so much as it is th=\r\ne most concentrated form of fantasy.&rdquo; This statement contradicts our =\r\neveryday assumptions about &ldquo;serious&rdquo; books as divergent from ot=\r\nher genres. It recognizes that we are, unexpectedly, accustomed to the hype=\r\nrbole of science fiction as a means to examine ourselves. The &lsquo;near f=\r\nuture,&rsquo; or even &lsquo;alternate reality&rsquo; of the books we will =\r\nread are, on some level, quite earnest and serious examinations of the gove=\r\nrnments, traditions, and assumptions of the present.</p>=0D=0A<p>We will be=\r\ngin the course by watching the film, Forbidden Planet. It was made in 1956 =\r\nwhen science fiction was a nascent genre, yet it already turned many an ide=\r\na on its head from its own time. The robot is not maniacal; humans become t=\r\nhe traveling invaders. It began the long tradition of atomic/hydrogen bomb =\r\nfears and, ultimately, seeks to probe the human psyche. As the film is base=\r\nd on Shakespeare&rsquo;s The Tempest, it is useful to place it, and the boo=\r\nks we will read, in the context of the evolution of fantasy writing.</p>=0D=\r\n=0A<p>TEXTS: The Cyberiad, by Stanislaw Lem.<br />Snow Crash, by Neal Steph=\r\nenson.<br />Gun, with Occasional Music, by Jonathan Lethem.</p>=0D=0A</bloc=\r\nkquote>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\">=\r\n<strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</fo=\r\nnt></em></strong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=\r\n=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"padding-left: 30px;\"><st=\r\nrong><font size=3D\"1\">ENGLISH SKILLS</font></strong></p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"c=\r\nenter\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D=\r\n\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a><stro=\r\nng><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></stron=\r\ng></p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"padding-left: 30px;\"><font size=3D\"1\"><strong>SAT V=\r\nERBAL<br /></strong>This course deals with the development of the verbal an=\r\nd test-taking skills necessary for taking the Verbal section of the SAT. If=\r\n relevant, based on class composition, guidance will also be given for Engl=\r\nish Regents preparation.</font></p>=0D=0A<p>&nbsp;</p>=0D=0A<hr />=0D=0A<p>=\r\n&nbsp;</p>=0D=0A<h3><a title=3D\"history\" name=3D\"history\"></a>HISTORY</h3>=\r\n=0D=0A<p>History is a crucial subject necessary for all students' understan=\r\nding of the basic knowledge, skills, and positive attitudes needed to becom=\r\ne responsible citizens and contributing members of society. History draws u=\r\npon geography, economics, the social sciences, behavioral sciences and huma=\r\nnities, while attempting to teach a wide range of critical and creative thi=\r\nnking skills.</p>=0D=0A<blockquote>=0D=0A<p><strong>GEOGRAPHY &amp; WORLD H=\r\nISTORY</strong>&nbsp;</p>=0D=0A<p>This is a year-long course designed to in=\r\ntroduce students to the physical and cultural geography of our world. Stude=\r\nnts will be encouraged to engage in-depth discussions of religion, diversit=\r\ny, environmental concerns, and to think critically about present-day confli=\r\ncts, political and economic systems, and the impact of globalization on bot=\r\nh developed and developing nations.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: World Geography and C=\r\nultures, Clencoe, 2008. Traditions &amp; Encounters. Bentlely, J., Ziegler,=\r\n H., McGraw-Hill, 2008.</p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.a=\r\nspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=\r\n=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-=\r\nsize: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>MODE=\r\nRN WORLD HISTORY</strong> <br />This is a course designed primarily for 10t=\r\nh grade students. It is comprised of two-semesters and begins where the Ear=\r\nly World History class ends--with the Renaissance in Western Europe. The co=\r\nurse will then proceed to examine the age of Enlightenment and the ensuing =\r\n&ldquo;Age of Revolution.&rdquo; The first semester ends with the formation=\r\n of the modern European nation-states, and the introduction of industrializ=\r\nation. The second semester begins with 19th century nationalism in Europe, =\r\nimperialism in Africa and Asia, continues through the two World Wars, and e=\r\nnds with key world events from post-1945 to the present. The course will ap=\r\nproach these historical topics from a global perspective and will give cons=\r\nideration to current events and geography: It is the school's belief that w=\r\ne cannot be expected to understand the present if we do not learn from the =\r\npast; moreover, we cannot discuss great world events in detail if we do not=\r\n know where and why they occurred.</p>=0D=0A<p>Another important goal of th=\r\nis course is to prepare students for the history portion of the Global Stud=\r\nies Regent&rsquo;s examination, which all Beekman students must pass prior =\r\nto graduation.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: Traditions &amp; Encounters. Bentlely, J.,=\r\n Ziegler, H., McGraw-Hill, 2008.</p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/p=\r\nageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small=\r\n;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a><strong><em><font style=\r\n=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<p><st=\r\nrong>UNITED STATES HISTORY</strong> <br />U.S. History is a year-long cours=\r\ne designed primarily for 11th grade students. The primary goal of this cour=\r\nse is to present students with historical information that will allow them =\r\nto form their own judgments, opinions, and perspectives of the history of t=\r\nhe United States. The course material asks students to examine the present =\r\nby looking at the political, social, and economic forces that have shaped t=\r\nhe past.</p>=0D=0A<p>The first semester begins with early European explorat=\r\nion of America and the establishment of the English Colonies, and continues=\r\n into the American Revolution, the founding of the country, and the writing=\r\n of the Constitution. The course then traces the growth and development of =\r\nthe U.S. into the mid 1800&rsquo;s, ending with an overview of the Civil Wa=\r\nr.</p>=0D=0A<p>The second semester begins with the era of Reconstruction fo=\r\nllowing the Civil War and continues into the Progressive movement. The cour=\r\nse then focuses on World War I and the &ldquo;boom times&rdquo; of the 1920=\r\ns that followed, the Great Depression, and the New Deal. The second semeste=\r\nr ends with an examination of the causes and final costs of World War II. I=\r\nn each unit, we will focus on the political, social, and economic forces th=\r\nat helped to shape the United States.</p>=0D=0A<p>In addition to classroom =\r\nlectures, the course includes field trips to places such as Ellis Island, t=\r\nhe New York Tenement Museum, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, as well as=\r\n going to screenings of relevant documentary films such as Rick Burns&rsquo=\r\n;s New York.</p>=0D=0A<p>Another important course goal is to prepare studen=\r\nts for the history portion of the U.S. History and Government Regent&rsquo;=\r\ns examination, which all Beekman students must pass prior to graduation.</p=\r\n>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: Todd and Curti&rsquo;s The American Nation. Boyer, Paul. Ho=\r\nlt, Rinehart, and Winston, 1995.</p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/p=\r\nageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small=\r\n;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a><strong><em><font style=\r\n=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<p><st=\r\nrong>ADVANCED UNITED STATES HISTORY<br /></strong>TEXT: Todd and Curti&rsqu=\r\no;s The American Nation. Boyer, Paul. Holt, Rinehart, and Winston, 1995.</p=\r\n>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><stron=\r\ng><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></e=\r\nm></strong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">=\r\n </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT<br /></=\r\nstrong>This is a one-semester, required course for 12th grade students. Stu=\r\ndents learn to recognize and think critically about national and internatio=\r\nnal problems, and to articulate their opinions about these issues. Upon com=\r\npletion of this course, it is hoped that the student will be able to succes=\r\nsfully defend his or her beliefs, cast an informed vote in elections, and p=\r\narticipate in the United States government as an educated citizen. Students=\r\n in this course are expected to have had experience in essay writing and an=\r\nalysis, as well as having a strong familiarity with U.S. history.</p>=0D=0A=\r\n<p>In this senior government course, we will discuss basic political theory=\r\n, review the United States Constitution, and examine current political syst=\r\nems in our country and throughout the world. In addition to studying the th=\r\nree branches of the federal government, specific topics of study may includ=\r\ne U.S. citizenship policy, civil liberties, public interest and opinion, an=\r\nd mass media. The course also focuses heavily on political ethics and polic=\r\ny.</p>=0D=0A<p>In order to think contextually about how our country operate=\r\ns, we will examine other political systems throughout history as well as th=\r\ne political and social history of the U.S. We will read works by philosophe=\r\nrs such as Hobbes, Rousseau, and Locke to provide a context for the ideals =\r\nset forth in the founding of the U.S. and in the formation of our constitut=\r\nition.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: Government in America: People, Politics and Policy=\r\n. Edwards, Wattenberg and Lineberry. Pearson Education, 2009.</p>=0D=0A<p s=\r\ntyle=3D\"text-align: center;\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><em>=\r\n<font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"><strong>back to top</strong=\r\n></font></em></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1=\r\n\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>ADVANCED GOVERNMENT<br /></str=\r\nong>This is a one-semester course for seniors. The course begins with basic=\r\n political theory and study of the founding of the nation and corresponding=\r\n documents, but incorporates the themes of freedom, order, and equality int=\r\no the curriculum. The course continues with an in-depth study of federalism=\r\n, in America and across the globe. In addition to studying the make-up of t=\r\nhe government, students will learn about electoral politics, lobbying, inte=\r\nrest groups, campaign finance, and the mass media. They will finish with an=\r\n incredible understanding of lawmaking and Congress, as well as pertinent c=\r\nonstitutional law and history. This course will assist students in preparin=\r\ng for the American Government AP exam, although additional outside study wi=\r\nll be required to cover all the topics on the test.&nbsp;</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT:=\r\n The Challenge of Democracy, 8th Edition.&nbsp;Janda, Berry,and Goldman.&nb=\r\nsp;Houghton Mifflin, Boston:&nbsp;2005.</p>=0D=0A<p>In addition to the text=\r\nbook, there will be a variety of supplemental materials, from essays to Sup=\r\nreme Court opinions.</p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-align: center;\"><a href=3D\"/=\r\npageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=\r\n=3D\"1\"><strong>back to top</strong></font></em></a><em><font style=3D\"font-=\r\nsize: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"><strong> </strong></font></em></p>=0D=0A<p><str=\r\nong>ECONOMICS<br /></strong>This is a required one-semester course. In it w=\r\ne will study basic types of economic systems, how they intersect with gover=\r\nnment, and how they affect the people who live under them. Specifically, we=\r\n will focus on the U.S. economy by looking at the two main branches: macroe=\r\nconomics and microeconomics.</p>=0D=0A<p>In order to understand how the U.S=\r\n. came to adopt its economic system, we will begin the course by looking at=\r\n some of the most discussed pieces written on economics by thinkers such as=\r\n Mill, Marx, Malthus, and Smith. This should provide a background that will=\r\n give context to thinking about our way of living compared to other countri=\r\nes today, as well as how people lived in the past.</p>=0D=0A<p>This course =\r\nshould also provide a framework to understand news reports and politicians =\r\nwhen they speak about inflation, the GNP, trusts, globalization, investment=\r\ns, balance of trade, taxes, etc.</p>=0D=0A<p>Even if you don't agree with M=\r\narx's viewpoint that money dictates every aspect of our lives, it is true t=\r\nhat money is inextricably tied to them. Whether in terms of business involv=\r\nement, your own wallet, or the government, understanding how these decision=\r\ns are made and how they affect you is an indispensible undertaking.</p>=0D=\r\n=0A<p>TEXT: Economics: Institutions and Analysis. Antell, Gerson. Amsco Sch=\r\nool Publications Inc. 2005. (4th Edition)</p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-align: =\r\ncenter;\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=\r\n=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a><s=\r\ntrong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></st=\r\nrong></p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-align: left;\"><strong>ADVANCED ECONOMICS</s=\r\ntrong></p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-align: center;\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?=\r\nid=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"=\r\n>back to top</font></em></strong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: =\r\nxx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-alig=\r\nn: left;\"><strong>ANTRHOPOLOGY<br /></strong>The scientific study of the or=\r\nigin, the behavior, and the physical, social, and cultural development of h=\r\numan beings.</p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-align: center;\"><a href=3D\"/pageview=\r\n.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=\r\n=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-=\r\nsize: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>MODE=\r\nRN POLITICS</strong> <br />This course is designed to continue where most W=\r\norld and US History classes leave off&mdash;in the post-World War II era. W=\r\ne will focus specifically on American domestic policies and international r=\r\nelations from 1945 to the present, looking at all material from a political=\r\n/historical perspective. The following is a list of the topics/issues we ma=\r\ny address: What did the end of WWII signify for the US and the other involv=\r\ned nations? How has the development of international organizations, such as=\r\n the United Nations, affected global politics over the last half-century? A=\r\nnalysis of the Cold War and anti-Communist climate of the 1950&rsquo;s; Ana=\r\nlysis of the ongoing Israeli-Palestinian struggle; Analysis of the evolutio=\r\nn of the Presidency from Eisenhower to G.W. Bush; How pop culture has been =\r\naffected by various eras in United States history: What effects has pop cul=\r\nture had on our youth? How did the Vietnam War, the Civil Rights Movement, =\r\nand the Woman&rsquo;s Movement shape US politics from the 1950&rsquo;s to t=\r\nhe 1970&rsquo;s? Analysis of current topics throughout the 1990&rsquo;s int=\r\no the 21st century, including the AIDS epidemic, The Green movement, The de=\r\ncline of the US during the Bush presidency, The US and the ongoing war on t=\r\nerrorism, and the war in Iraq.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: Todd and Curti&rsquo;s The=\r\n American Nation. Boyer, Paul. Holt, Rinehart, and Winston, 1995.</p>=0D=0A=\r\n<p><strong>INTERNATIONAL POLITICS</strong> <br />TEXT: Various articles, te=\r\nxts, and films</p>=0D=0A</blockquote>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/=\r\npageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-smal=\r\nl;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a></p>=0D=0A<hr />=0D=0A<h=\r\n3><a title=3D\"math\" name=3D\"math\"></a>MATHEMATICS</h3>=0D=0A<p>Knowledge of=\r\n mathematics and a familiarity with its applications are essential in today=\r\n&rsquo;s changing world. Selection of the correct course sequence is the si=\r\nngle most important factor for success in mathematics at the high school le=\r\nvel. The courses offered are designed to serve students with differing abil=\r\nities, interests, and career aspirations and to enable students to experien=\r\nce success in mathematics.</p>=0D=0A<blockquote>=0D=0A<p><strong>ALGEBRA I<=\r\n/strong>&nbsp;<br /><em>Prerequisite: Successful mastery of Pre-Algebra top=\r\nics.</em><br />Algebra I introduces various topics that comprise elementary=\r\n algebra. Students not only acquire important algebraic skills to simplify =\r\nproblems and solve equations, they also gain an understanding of the concep=\r\nts that lie at the heart of algebraic manipulations. In so doing, this cour=\r\nse directly prepares the student for the questions concerning algebra on th=\r\ne mathematics sections of the SAT and Regents exams, as well as providing a=\r\n solid foundation on which to build in subsequent mathematics courses such =\r\nas Geometry and Algebra II/Trigonometry. Major topics include modeling alge=\r\nbraic problems; solving and graphing equations and inequalities; systems of=\r\n equations; ratios and proportions; properties and use of exponents; mathem=\r\natical modeling using functions, tables and graphs; number patterns, counti=\r\nng methods and permutations; polynomials and factoring; radical expressions=\r\n and equations.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT:&nbsp;<em>Algebra 1</em>. Bellman, Bragg, =\r\net al. Prentice Hall Mathematics Series; Pearson/Prentice&nbsp;Hall&nbsp;Pu=\r\nblications.</p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D222=\r\n39#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to=\r\n top</font></em></strong></a></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>ALGEBRA II / TRIGONOMETRY=\r\n</strong> <br /><em>Prerequisite: Algebra I&nbsp;and Geometry.</em><br />Th=\r\nis course reviews and extends the mathematical investigations of the previo=\r\nus two courses into the study of general function theory, trigonometry, sys=\r\ntems of equations and inequalities, and the theory of specific functions an=\r\nd their inverses. It constitutes the third year course in the Mathematics D=\r\nepartment. Semester One is devoted to a review of exponential rules and oth=\r\ner basic principles, solutions of various types of equations and inequaliti=\r\nes in one variable, coordinate geometry and the graphing of lines, circles,=\r\n and parabolas, and an introduction to basic function theory.&nbsp;Semester=\r\n Two investigates advanced function theory, trigonometry, logarithmic and e=\r\nxponential functions and equations, and systems of simultaneous equations a=\r\nnd inequalities.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: <em>Algebra &amp; Trigonometry</em>, Mic=\r\nhael Sullivan. Prentice Hall, 6th Edition.</p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a =\r\nhref=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size=\r\n: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a></p>=0D=0A<p><s=\r\ntrong>GEOMETRY <br /></strong><em>Prerequisite: Algebra I.</em><br />This c=\r\nourse reinforces and extends the mathematical foundation established in our=\r\n previous course Algebra I.&nbsp;It offers an in-depth investigation of the=\r\n topics of a yearlong course in Geometry while revisiting numerous topics s=\r\ntudied in Algebra I from a different perspective. Semester One is devoted t=\r\no a study of basic principles, reasoning and proof, parallel and perpendicu=\r\nlar lines, congruent triangle theory, and special relationships within tria=\r\nngles.&nbsp;Important theorems from semester one include the isosceles tria=\r\nngle theorem, and the proof that all triangles have angles whose sum is 180=\r\n degrees. Semester Two is devoted to a study of quadrilaterals, area, perim=\r\neter, and circumference, similarity theory and right triangle trigonometry.=\r\n Major objectives of the second semester include a thorough understanding o=\r\nf the Pythagorean Theorem, and an ability to find measurements indirectly u=\r\nsing trigonometry and a calculator.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: <em>Geometry</em>. Ba=\r\nss, et al. Prentice Hall Mathematics Series; Pearson/Prentice&nbsp;Hall&nbs=\r\np;Publications.&nbsp;</p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.asp=\r\nx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"=\r\n1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>PRE-CALCULUS<br=\r\n /></strong>This course is a rigorous one-year introduction to the major to=\r\npics of Pre-Calculus. Students will learn about topics that are beyond the =\r\nscope of both Algebra II and Sequential Math III, but which are necessary t=\r\no understand Calculus. This course is recommended for any student who is in=\r\nterested and proficient in mathematics and wishes to expand and extend his/=\r\nher knowledge in this area by pursuing the subject beyond the framework of =\r\nthe basic algebra and geometry course offerings.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: <em>Pre-=\r\nCalculus</em>. Sullivan and Sullivan. 1998 Edition.</p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"ce=\r\nnter\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"=\r\nfont-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a></p>=\r\n=0D=0A<p><strong>CALCULUS</strong><br />This course provides students with =\r\na strong background in college-level Calculus. Problem solving is emphasize=\r\nd along with applications. The material covered prepares students for a var=\r\niety of college majors as well as preparing students for the AP exam (AB or=\r\n BC) that is administered each May. The topics covered in this class are: L=\r\nimits &amp; Derivatives, Differentiation Rules, Applications of Differentia=\r\ntion, Integrals, Applications of Integration as well as Differential Equati=\r\nons. These chapters represent material covered in two semesters at most col=\r\nleges and universities throughout the country.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: <em>Calcul=\r\nus Early Transcendentals. </em>Anton, Bivens, Davis.&nbsp;7th Ed.</p>=0D=0A=\r\n<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><=\r\nfont style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></str=\r\nong></a></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>SAT MATHEMATICS</strong><br />This course offe=\r\nrs a comprehensive preparation for the morning SAT Mathematics sections of =\r\nthe College Board Examinations.&nbsp; The SAT Math class will go over exami=\r\nnation grading procedures and offer the best test taking strategies for eac=\r\nh section.&nbsp;This class will also embark on a thorough review of the mat=\r\nhematical topics under examination in the SATs with an eye to the dominance=\r\n of the topics in question.&nbsp;Finally, the course will chart individual =\r\nstudents' progress by the systematic taking and grading of actual and simul=\r\nated SAT Math exams.</p>=0D=0A<p>Once the December SAT exams have been take=\r\nn, the course turns its attention to additional preparation needed for the =\r\nMath A Regents exam as mandated by the State of New York, and given during =\r\nthe January exam period.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: <em>Barron's Review Text:&nbsp;M=\r\nath SAT I Examination</em>. Richard J. Andres and Joyce Bernstein.</p>=0D=\r\n=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><e=\r\nm><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></=\r\nstrong></a></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>FINITE MATHEMATICS</strong><br /><em>Prereq=\r\nuisite: Algebra I&nbsp;and Geometry.</em><br />This elective in Mathematics=\r\n, reinforces and extends (from both within and without) the mathematical fo=\r\nundation that each student brings to the course. One aim of Finite Mathemat=\r\nics is to strengthen a student's basic skills in algebra and geometry in ac=\r\ncordance with the standards of the NYS Math Regents.&nbsp;A second basic ai=\r\nm is to enrich the student's mathematical foundation with explorations of t=\r\nopics generally taught outside the confines of Algebra and Geometry-topics =\r\nsuch as set theory, infinite sets, abstract group theory, number theory, an=\r\nd probability.&nbsp;Finite Mathematics is both practical in its emphasis on=\r\n review and interesting in its varied selection of intriguing mathematical =\r\ntopics.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: <em>Mathematical Ideas</em>. Miller, Heeren, and =\r\nHornsby.&nbsp;Pearson Publications, a division of Addison-Wesley.</p>=0D=0A=\r\n<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><=\r\nfont style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></str=\r\nong></a></p>=0D=0A<hr />=0D=0A<h3><a title=3D\"science\" name=3D\"science\"></a=\r\n>SCIENCE</h3>=0D=0A<p>The main goal of the science program is to help stude=\r\nnts obtain the scientific awareness needed to function as an effective memb=\r\ner of society. The content is intended to foster positive attitudes towards=\r\n science, to increase student understanding of science knowledge, processes=\r\n, and the connections among science, technology, and society, and to provid=\r\ne an appropriate foundation for further studies and careers in science. Whi=\r\nle these goals apply to all the courses, a specific program should be chose=\r\nn on the basis of interest and need in terms of future goals.</p>=0D=0A<blo=\r\nckquote>=0D=0A<p><strong>BIOLOGY</strong><br />This year-long course is a r=\r\nigorous introduction to high school biology designed to build on students p=\r\nrior knowledge of various plant and animal biological processes. Students w=\r\nill develop skills in organizing information, making observations, and reco=\r\nrding scientific data / preparing lab reports. Laboratory periods are used =\r\nto reinforce the topic currently being considered, allowing students to acq=\r\nuire reasoning skills necessary in understanding and conducting scientific =\r\ninvestigations.</p>=0D=0A<p>Topics covered throughout the year are: The sci=\r\nence of biology, discovering life, cells, energy and life, cell reproductio=\r\nn, genetics and inheritance, how genes work, gene technology, evolution and=\r\n natural selection, animal behavior, ecosystems and ecology, classifying li=\r\nving things, bacteria and viruses, protista, fungi and plants, plant form a=\r\nnd function, the human body, human nervous system, chemical regulation, cir=\r\nculation and respiration, the immune system, digestion and excretion, and h=\r\numan reproduction.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: Biology:Exploring Life. Campbell, Will=\r\niamson, Heyden. Prentice Hall, 2006</p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D=\r\n\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-sm=\r\nall;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>E=\r\nCOLOGY</strong><br />This&nbsp;one-semester elective is designed to introdu=\r\nce students to the environmental science aspect of ecology. Students will d=\r\nevelop skills in organizing information, making observations, and recording=\r\n scientific data. Students will acquire reasoning skills used in scientific=\r\n investigations.</p>=0D=0A<p>Topics covered throughout the year are: Global=\r\n perspectives of environmental science, living things in ecosystems, how ec=\r\nosystems work, kinds of ecosystems, water, air, atmosphere and climate, lan=\r\nd, food, biodiversity, energy, waste, population growth, and sustainable de=\r\nvelopment.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: Environmental Science. Arms, Karen. Holt, Rine=\r\nhart and Winston: New York. 2000.</p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/=\r\npageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-smal=\r\nl;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>AST=\r\nRONOMY</strong><br />This one-semester elective is an introduction to the f=\r\nield of astronomy.&nbsp;It provides a survey of modern understanding of the=\r\n cosmos, including the formation of our solar system and galaxy, and our pl=\r\nace in the universe.&nbsp;A major course objective is to provide an appreci=\r\nation for how our lives are connected at the most fundamental level to the =\r\nSun, Moon, planets, stars, and galaxies that fill our skies.</p>=0D=0A<p>Co=\r\nurse content&nbsp;includes: The Big Bang; star and planet formation; unders=\r\ntanding energy, motion, and gravity; the early history of science; discover=\r\ning the universe on an individual level; recent insight into the possibilit=\r\ny of life elsewhere in the universe; the challenges of interstellar travel =\r\nand manned exploration of the cosmos.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: The Essential Cosmi=\r\nc Perspective, 3rd edition.&nbsp;Bennett, Donahue, Schneider, Voit. Pearson=\r\n Education: San Francisco 2005.</p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pa=\r\ngeview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;=\r\n\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>CHEMI=\r\nSTRY<br /></strong>This year-long course is designed to introduce students =\r\nto the physical science of chemistry. Students will develop skills in organ=\r\nizing information, making observations, and recording scientific data. Labo=\r\nratory periods are used to reinforce the topic currently being considered a=\r\nnd allow students to acquire reasoning skills used in scientific investigat=\r\nions. Pre-requisite: To have taken or be taking Algebra II / Trigonometry.<=\r\n/p>=0D=0A<p>Topics covered throughout the year are: Matter, chemical founda=\r\ntions (i.e., elements, atoms, and ions), nomenclature, measurements and cal=\r\nculation, chemical composition, chemical reactions, reactions in aqueous so=\r\nlutions, chemical quantities, energy, modern atomic theory, chemical bondin=\r\ng, liquids and solids, solutions, acids and bases, equilibrium, oxidation-r=\r\neduction reaction and electrochemistry, radioactivity and nuclear energy, o=\r\nrganic chemistry, and biochemistry.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: World of Chemistry. E=\r\nditors Zumdahl, S., Zumdahl, S., and DeCoste, D. McDougal. Littell: New Yor=\r\nk. 2002.</p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#=\r\ntop\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to to=\r\np</font></em></strong></a></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>PHYSICS<br /></strong>This u=\r\npper level year-long science course provides a college-level introduction t=\r\no the major topics of physics. In order to fully understand and apply physi=\r\ncal principles, students should have a thorough grasp of advanced algebra-b=\r\nased problem solving skills.</p>=0D=0A<p>The emphasis of this course is to =\r\nunderstand the fundamental principles governing physics; number crunching a=\r\nnd absolute answers are not the primary objectives in this course. Topics c=\r\novered throughout the year are: Simple motion of vectors &amp; scalars, vel=\r\nocity and acceleration, vectors diagrams including the addition and subtrac=\r\ntion of vectors, gravity, forces, Newton&rsquo;s Laws of Motion, work, powe=\r\nr, energy, thermal energy, fluids: density, pressure, buoyancy, waves, soun=\r\nd, light: reflection &amp; refraction, lenses, electricity, electric circui=\r\nts, magnetism, atomic theories, and the nucleus &amp; nuclear reactions.</p=\r\n>=0D=0A<p>TEXT:&nbsp;Physics, Principles and Problems, Glencoe 2009, Zietze=\r\nnwitz &amp; Neff</p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=\r\n=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">b=\r\nack to top</font></em></strong></a></p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-align: left;\"=\r\n><strong>CONCEPTUAL PHYSICS<br /></strong>This is a year-long course which =\r\nsurveys the fundamental topics in physics. In this class we will focus on t=\r\nhe properties and interactions of matter and energy. The main objective of =\r\nthe class is to make students aware of how physics relates to their everyda=\r\ny lives and their world as well as to develop critical thinking. Although t=\r\nhe class concentrates on the conceptual components of Physics, we will use =\r\nelementary mathematics to describe our observations. You are expected to kn=\r\now or learn any math that is used in the class.&nbsp;</p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"=\r\ntext-align: left;\"><br />Text: Conceptual Physics, Paul Hewitt, Addison-Wes=\r\nley, 10th edition. &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-align: cen=\r\nter;\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"=\r\nfont-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a><stron=\r\ng><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong=\r\n></p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-align: left;\"><strong>THEORETICAL PHYSICS<br />=\r\n<span style=3D\"font-weight: normal;\">This course is a one-year math intensi=\r\nve science class of major topics in physics, with a stronger focus on Moder=\r\nn Physics.&nbsp; You will learn about the dynamic relationships between wav=\r\nes and energy, electricity and magnetism, as well as atomic and nuclear phy=\r\nsics.&nbsp; Modern applications of the preceding principles will be emphasi=\r\nzed.&nbsp; In order to fully understand and apply physical principles, you =\r\nshould have a thorough grasp of algebra and trigonometry-based problem solv=\r\ning skills.</span></strong></p>=0D=0A<strong><span style=3D\"text-decoration=\r\n: underline;\"><br /></span></strong>Text : Physics, Principles and Problems=\r\n, Glencoe 2009, Zitzenwitz &amp; Neff &nbsp; &nbsp;=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-a=\r\nlign: center;\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font =\r\nstyle=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"><br />back to top</font></em></st=\r\nrong></a></p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-align: left;\"><strong>PSYCHOLOGY I<br /=\r\n></strong>In this introductory course, students will explore three large sc=\r\nhools of thought: psychoanalysis, behaviorism and cognitive-social learning=\r\n theory. Through the study of articles, handouts, films and a textbook, stu=\r\ndents will increase their insight into the human mind, body and behavior.</=\r\np>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-align: left;\">Text: Psychology (Fourth Edition) by=\r\n Saul Kassin</p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-align: center;\"><a href=3D\"/pageview=\r\n.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=\r\n=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a></p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-align=\r\n: left;\"><strong>PSYCHOLOGY II<br /></strong><em>Pre-Requisite: Psychology =\r\nI</em><br />In this Second Semester course, students apply their knowledge =\r\nof personality development to the following topics: gender differences, the=\r\nories of motivation, influence without awareness, intelligence and psycholo=\r\ngical disorders. Carl Jung will also be explored in depth.</p>=0D=0A<p styl=\r\ne=3D\"text-align: left;\">Text: Psychology (Fourth Edition) by Saul Kassin</p=\r\n>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-align: center;\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D2223=\r\n9#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to =\r\ntop</font></em></strong></a></p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-align: center;\">&nbs=\r\np;</p>=0D=0A<p><strong>HEALTH EDUCATION</strong> <br />This required one-se=\r\nmester course in health is a serious, in-depth approach which focuses on te=\r\naching students the responsibility of caring for their emotional, physical,=\r\n and social welfare as young adults, and perhaps, eventually, as parents. T=\r\nhis class is designed to provide information, ask questions, solve problems=\r\n, and support students in a sensitive, confidential environment. Although t=\r\nhere are some objectively right or wrong answers in this subject, much of t=\r\nhe most important learning involves questions that do not have clear-cut an=\r\nswers. Therefore, besides quizzes and tests for each chapter, there will al=\r\nso be short essays and reading responses throughout the semester.</p>=0D=0A=\r\n<p>Health is a required class in the state of New York. At the Beekman Scho=\r\nol, this course is taken very seriously. It is our belief that in order to =\r\nunderstand how to stay healthy and fit, one must have a familiarity with ba=\r\nsic biology and physiology. Once these concepts are understood, Health stud=\r\nents can take an active role participating in their own health care.</p>=0D=\r\n=0A<p>A range of topics which may be covered throughout a semester are: Mak=\r\ning healthy choices, personality and self esteem, managing stress, mental d=\r\nisorders and suicide, psychological development, adulthood, aging, and deat=\r\nh, food and nutrition, personal care, alcohol, tobacco, preventing drug abu=\r\nse, infectious diseases, AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases, and noninf=\r\nectious diseases and disabilities.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: Health Skills for Well=\r\nness. Pruitt, Crumpler. Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey: Prentice Hall. 1994.<=\r\n/p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><str=\r\nong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font><=\r\n/em></strong></a></p>=0D=0A</blockquote>=0D=0A<hr />=0D=0A<h3><a title=3D\"f=\r\noreign\" name=3D\"foreign\"></a>FOREIGN LANGUAGE</h3>=0D=0A<blockquote>=0D=0A<=\r\np><strong>SPANISH </strong><strong>I</strong><br />At the end of this cours=\r\ne, students will be able to hold a basic conversation and make simple reque=\r\nsts similar to the ones found in a traveler&rsquo;s language guide. They wi=\r\nll be able to introduce themselves, give information about themselves, orde=\r\nr a meal in a restaurant, shop, count money, ask for directions, and seek m=\r\nedical care. And last but not least, make friends.</p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"tex=\r\nt-align: left;\">TEXT: Spanish for Mastery I (Textbook and Workbook). Valett=\r\ne and Valette.</p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-align: center;\"><a href=3D\"/pagevi=\r\new.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" si=\r\nze=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"fon=\r\nt-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>SP=\r\nANISH </strong><strong>II<br /></strong><em>Prerequisite: Spanish I</em><br=\r\n />The objective of Spanish II is to obtain proficiency in listening, speak=\r\ning, reading, and writing in the target language. In addition, students wil=\r\nl acquire a firm linguistic base, which is the foundation of effective comm=\r\nunication and meaningful language proficiency. In order to develop a more c=\r\noncise world-view, students will learn to situate the language within the c=\r\nontext of the contemporary Spanish&ndash;speaking world and its cultures. T=\r\nhe emphasis in this course sequence is to actively apply the fundamentals t=\r\nhat were introduced in the preliminary Spanish course (Spanish I). Students=\r\n will develop their communication skills by learning to express complex tho=\r\nughts and ideas. Among the verb forms studied are the present, the imperfec=\r\nt, the subjunctive, the reflexive, the imperative, the future, the future p=\r\nerfect, and the conditional. To facilitate thinking in the target language =\r\nin an abstract manner, a variety of literary texts are read and discussed. =\r\nIn addition, specific attention will be paid to correct pronunciation and d=\r\niction.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: Spanish for Mastery II (Textbook and Workbook). V=\r\nalette and Valette.</p>=0D=0A</blockquote>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=\r\n=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx=\r\n-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a><strong><em><font s=\r\ntyle=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<b=\r\nlockquote>=0D=0A<p><strong>SPANISH </strong><strong>III<br /></strong><em>P=\r\nrerequisite: Spanish II</em><strong><br /></strong>The objective of Spanish=\r\n III is to refine listening, speaking, reading, and writing in the target l=\r\nanguage. In addition, students will strengthen and expand their linguistic =\r\nbase, thus enhancing the foundation of effective communication and meaningf=\r\nul language proficiency. Students will continue to learn to situate the lan=\r\nguage within the context of the contemporary Spanish&ndash;speaking world a=\r\nnd its cultures. The emphasis in this course sequence is to actively apply =\r\nthe fundamentals that were introduced in the primary and secondary Spanish =\r\ncourses (Spanish I and Spanish II). Students will develop their communicati=\r\non skills by learning to express complex thoughts and ideas. Written assign=\r\nments of a more substantial length will afford students the opportunity to =\r\nwrite in a more academic manner. Among the verb forms reviewed are the pres=\r\nent, the imperfect, the preterit, the reflexive, the imperative, the future=\r\n, the future perfect, the conditional, the present perfect, and the subjunc=\r\ntive and imperfect subjunctive. Students will learn grammar within the cont=\r\next of various authors, such as Ana Mar&iacute;a Matute, Horacio Quiroga, a=\r\nnd Luis C. Infante. The literary context in which students encounter the la=\r\nnguage will allow them to think critically about the ideas and situations p=\r\nresented by the authors. In addition, specific attention will be paid to co=\r\nrrect pronunciation and diction, and the subtle nuances of spoken language<=\r\n/p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: Spanish for Mastery III (Textbook and Workbook). Valette =\r\nand Valette.</p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22=\r\n239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back t=\r\no top</font></em></strong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-smal=\r\nl;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-align: left=\r\n;\"><strong>SPANISH IV</strong></p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-align: center;\"><a=\r\n href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-siz=\r\ne: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a><strong><em><f=\r\nont style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=\r\n=0A<p style=3D\"text-align: left;\"><strong><font size=3D\"1\">ESL<br /></font>=\r\n</strong>This course is designed to strengthen English language skills thro=\r\nugh the use of a content-based curriculum. Academic English is emphasized a=\r\nnd will be reinforced using a variety of texts, writing assignments, speaki=\r\nng activities, and cooperative learning projects.</p>=0D=0A<p>Since student=\r\ns might be entering at different levels, grammar and vocabulary will be pre=\r\nsented in relation to other Beekman courses. Students will write simple sen=\r\ntence patterns or will expand their writing skills to include more complex =\r\nvarieties of sentences &nbsp;and will be expected to participate in convers=\r\nation and communicate orally using conventions of standard English.&nbsp;</=\r\np>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: Course materials will be drawn from various sources.</p>=\r\n=0D=0A</blockquote>=0D=0A<hr />=0D=0A<h3><a title=3D\"finearts\" name=3D\"fine=\r\narts\"></a>FINE ARTS</h3>=0D=0A<p>As students acquire basic skills and knowl=\r\nedge in the fine arts, their understanding enables them to perceive how fin=\r\ne arts standards define excellence, allowing them to recognize excellence i=\r\nn the work of others, and to achieve excellence in their own performances. =\r\nThus, a program of study in the fine arts can serve as the foundation for p=\r\nersonal achievement at the highest possible level.</p>=0D=0A<blockquote>=0D=\r\n=0A<p><strong>3-DIMENSIONAL ART<br /></strong>Students experiment with and =\r\nlearn different methods of three-dimensional design. They complete projects=\r\n ranging from the creation of everyday utilitarian objects to purely invent=\r\ned or abstract forms, or models of carefully observed still-lifes. Various =\r\nconstruction and assemblage techniques are explored. Students learn the wor=\r\nking qualities of a variety of materials including cardboard, hot glue, lig=\r\nht sheet metal, paper, wood, plaster, wire, wax, cloth, papier-m&acirc;ch&e=\r\nacute; , pumpkins and gourds. Innovation and creativity are encouraged, and=\r\n experimentation with scale and unusual combinations of materials is especi=\r\nally encouraged. Later in the class, students are introduced to the basics =\r\nof adding color to sculpture and the use of acrylic paints.</p>=0D=0A<p>Per=\r\niodically, students view one another&rsquo;s sculptures, constructions and =\r\nassemblages and discuss them as a class. Students learn to carefully look a=\r\nt their peers&rsquo; work as well as their own and make informed comments. =\r\nThe qualities of texture, shape, weight, form, stability, choice of materia=\r\nls, and color are stressed. The class also includes an art history componen=\r\nt. Students visit art exhibitions and refer to art history books and specif=\r\nic artists. As appropriate, students discuss major concerns of sculpture fr=\r\nom the past and learn how artists have worked differently in three dimensio=\r\nns.</p>=0D=0A</blockquote>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.as=\r\npx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D=\r\n\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-siz=\r\ne: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<blockquote>=0D=0A=\r\n<p><strong>DRAWING</strong><br />This course exposes students to the elemen=\r\nts and expressive qualities of line, including contour, gesture, and callig=\r\nraphy. Students explore formal aspects of two-dimensional artwork in the be=\r\nginning of the course, then, after studying animated films and visiting the=\r\n Drawing Center in Soho and a museum, they devise a final project of their =\r\nchoice.</p>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#t=\r\nop\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top=\r\n</font></em></strong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" s=\r\nize=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<p><strong>DIGITAL PHOTOGRAPHY<br=\r\n /></strong>Students will be introduced to the basic techniques of digital =\r\nphotography through a series of photography assignments and hands-on digita=\r\nl experience. Students will explore their creativity through the medium of =\r\nphotography by learning how to control depth, motion, and the basic study o=\r\nf light.&nbsp;</p>=0D=0A</blockquote>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-align: center; =\r\npadding-left: 30px;\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em>=\r\n<font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></st=\r\nrong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </fon=\r\nt></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<blockquote>=0D=0A<p><strong>FILMMAKING &amp; FIL=\r\nM CRITICISM<br /></strong>The film course at The Beekman School consists of=\r\n two parts: First, students learn film language, structure, philosophy, and=\r\n vocabulary by using a college-level textbook and watching and taking notes=\r\n on various important films of the 20th and 21st century. During the second=\r\n half of the course, students learn how to make short films using the conce=\r\npts taught in the first half of the course. Notable films continue to be ex=\r\namined and deconstructed; higher-level film theory is introduced. There is =\r\nalso a focus on the business of film, pre and post-production, creating bud=\r\ngets, and the examination of the pros and cons of the director as &ldquo;au=\r\nteur.&rdquo;</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: Understanding Movies by Louis Giannetti, 8th=\r\n Edition, Prentice Hall, 1999.</p>=0D=0A</blockquote>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"cent=\r\ner\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"fo=\r\nnt-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a><strong>=\r\n<em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong><=\r\n/p>=0D=0A<h3><a title=3D\"tech\" name=3D\"tech\"></a>TECHNOLOGY COURSES</h3>=0D=\r\n=0A<p>Students develop knowledge and skills related to computers and techno=\r\nlogy so that they will be prepared to enter today&rsquo;s high tech work en=\r\nvironment. Topics covered in these courses include a attaining a working kn=\r\nowledge of computer packages for personal or business use, computer graphic=\r\ns, computer animation, photography, traditional animation, and poster and w=\r\neb design layouts.</p>=0D=0A<blockquote>=0D=0A<p><br /><strong>COMPUTER ANI=\r\nMATION</strong><br />This is a one-semester computer course that introduces=\r\n students to computer animation using the industry-standard software progra=\r\nm Macromedia Flash.</p>=0D=0A<p>Throughout this course, students will learn=\r\n how to create vector graphics using Flash&rsquo;s tools and will then lear=\r\nn how to animate these graphics. At the completion of this course, students=\r\n will create an interactive Flash movie as their final project.</p>=0D=0A</=\r\nblockquote>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#t=\r\nop\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top=\r\n</font></em></strong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" s=\r\nize=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<blockquote>=0D=0A<p><strong>COMP=\r\nUTER ART</strong><br />This is a one-semester computer course that introduc=\r\nes students to digital print design using the industry-standard software pr=\r\nogram Adobe Photoshop . Throughout this course, students will engage in sev=\r\neral print projects that develop a general understanding of creating, manip=\r\nulating, and improving digital images using Adobe Photoshop.</p>=0D=0A<p st=\r\nyle=3D\"text-align: center;\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><stro=\r\nng><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></=\r\nem></strong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"=\r\n> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A</blockquote>=0D=0A<blockquote>=0D=0A<p><s=\r\ntrong>DIGITAL PUBLISHING</strong><br />Digital Publishing&nbsp;is a one-sem=\r\nester introductory course to Graphic Design that involves inquiry into the =\r\nnature of graphic design and visual problem solving. Topics in this course =\r\ninclude, symbols, typography, basic components of design and visual concept=\r\ns. This course will also introduce students to production procedures for pr=\r\nint media as well as graphic design history. Students will work both indepe=\r\nndently and collaboratively. Students will continue exploring Adobe Photosh=\r\nop&nbsp;and Illustrator as well as develop an understanding of layout using=\r\n Adobe In Design.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEXT: Scott McCloud: Understanding Comics, Ch=\r\nip Kidd: The Cheese Monkeys: A Novel In Two Semesters, Alexander White: The=\r\n Elements of Graphic Design: Space, Unity, Page, Architecture, and Type</p>=\r\n=0D=0A</blockquote>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=\r\n=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">b=\r\nack to top</font></em></strong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx=\r\n-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<blockquote>=0D=0A<p><s=\r\ntrong>WEB DESIGN</strong><br />This is a one-semester computer course that =\r\nintroduces students to web design, using the industry-standard software pro=\r\ngram Dreamweaver.</p>=0D=0A<p>Throughout this course, students will gain a =\r\ngeneral understanding of the WWW, HTML and the GoLive interface, will learn=\r\n to create web sites using various design techniques, and will create and o=\r\nptimize images for the web using Photoshop/ImageReady. Additionally, studen=\r\nts will learn to organize, manage, and publish their sites.</p>=0D=0A<p>TEX=\r\nT: Don't Make Me Think: A Common Sense Approach to Web Usability by Steve K=\r\nrug</p>=0D=0A</blockquote>=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.as=\r\npx?id=3D22239#top\"><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D=\r\n\"1\">back to top</font></em></strong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-siz=\r\ne: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"paddin=\r\ng-left: 30px;\"><strong>VIDEO PRODUCTION<br /></strong>This is a one-semeste=\r\nr computer course that introduces students to Video and audio editing throu=\r\ngh the use of Digital Camcorders and the software programs <em>iMovie</em> =\r\nand <em>GarageBand</em>.&nbsp; Students will learn the basics of video and =\r\nmovie creation from beginning to end including preproduction and storyboard=\r\ning, shot angles, capturing and importing footage, scoring music and export=\r\ning. At the completion of this course, students will have created several v=\r\nideo shorts in both a collaborative and independent setting.</p>=0D=0A<p st=\r\nyle=3D\"text-align: center;\"><a href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\"><stro=\r\nng><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></=\r\nem></strong></a><strong><em><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"=\r\n> </font></em></strong></p>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"padding-left: 30px; text-align=\r\n: left;\"><!--  --><!--  --><!--[if gte mso 10]> <mce:style><!   /* Style De=\r\nfinitions */  table.MsoNormalTable \t{mso-style-name:\"Table Normal\"; \tmso-ts=\r\ntyle-rowband-size:0; \tmso-tstyle-colband-size:0; \tmso-style-noshow:yes; \tms=\r\no-style-parent:\"\"; \tmso-padding-alt:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt; \tmso-para-margin:0=\r\nin; \tmso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt; \tmso-pagination:widow-orphan; \tfont-si=\r\nze:10.0pt; \tfont-family:\"Times New Roman\"; \tmso-ansi-language:#0400; \tmso-f=\r\nareast-language:#0400; \tmso-bidi-language:#0400;}  > <! [endif] ></div>=0D=\r\n=0A<div style=3D\"padding-left: 30px;\" mce_style=3D\"padding-left: 30px;\" mce=\r\n_tmp=3D\"1\">Text: Jeff Carlson: iMovie '08 & iDVD '08</div>=0D=0A<div mce_tm=\r\np=3D\"1\">&nbsp;</div>=0D=0A<div style=3D\"padding-left: 30px; text-align: cen=\r\nter;\" mce_style=3D\"padding-left: 30px; text-align: center;\" mce_tmp=3D\"1\"><=\r\na href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22239#top\" mce_href=3D\"/pageview.aspx?id=3D22=\r\n239#top\"><b><i><font style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" mce_style=3D\"font-size:=\r\n xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\">back to top</font></i></b></a><b><i><font style=3D\"f=\r\nont-size: xx-small;\" mce_style=3D\"font-size: xx-small;\" size=3D\"1\"> </font>=\r\n</i></b></div>=0D=0A</blockquote>=0D=0A</P></BLOCKQUO ></div>=0D=0A</blockq=\r\nuo ></div>=0D=0A</blockquo ></div>=0D=0A</blockquo ></div>=0D=0A</blockquo =\r\n></div>=0D=0A</blockquo ></div>=0D=0A</blockquo ></div>=0D=0A</blockquo ></=\r\ndiv>=0D=0A</blockquo ></div>=0D=0A</blockquo ></div>=0D=0A</blockquo ></div=\r\n>=0D=0A</blockquo ></div>=0D=0A</blockquo ></div>=0D=0A<div mce_tmp=3D\"1\">T=\r\nhis is a one-semester computer course that introduces students to Video and=\r\n audio editing through the use of Digital Camcorders and the software progr=\r\nams <i>iMovie</i> and <i>GarageBand</i>.&nbsp; Students will learn the basi=\r\ncs of video and movie creation from beginning to end including preproductio=\r\nn and storyboarding, shot angles, capturing and importing footage, scoring =\r\nmusic and exporting. colspan=3D\"2\" rowspan=3D\"1\"  width=3D\"680\"  id=3D\"c=\r\n_395304\" ><div class=3D\"div1\"><div class=3D\"div2\"><h6>Academics&nbsp;:: Fac=\r\nulty</h6></div></div></td><td colspan=3D\"1\" rowspan=3D\"6\"  width=3D\"20\"  id=\r\n=3D\"c_395306\" ></td></tr><tr class=3D\"r2\" id=3D\"r2_22334\"><td colspan=3D\"2\"=\r\n rowspan=3D\"1\"  width=3D\"680\"  align=3D\"left\"  id=3D\"c_395307\" ><div class=\r\n=3D\"div1\"><div class=3D\"div2\"><p>The Beekman faculty is highly regarded for=\r\n&nbsp;its skill in motivating&nbsp;students,&nbsp;discovering new paths for=\r\n learning, and building student confidence.&nbsp;They bring a diverse array=\r\n of academic knowledge and fresh thinking to the Beekman learning experienc=\r\ne.</p>=0D=0A<p>Our headmaster, George Higgins, has been at the school since=\r\n 1980, first as a teacher, then as Assistant Headmaster, before serving the=\r\n school as Headmaster.</p>=0D=0A<h2>More Than Teaching</h2>=0D=0A<p>In addi=\r\ntion to teaching, faculty members also act as advisers to small groups of s=\r\ntudents. Faculty advisers review progress reports with students and hold me=\r\netings periodically to listen to&nbsp;their concerns and discuss upcoming e=\r\nvents and projects.</p>=0D=0A<table style=3D\"height: 149px; background-colo=\r\nr: #ffffff; border: #330066 0pt solid;\" border=3D\"0\" cellspacing=3D\"0\" cell=\r\npadding=3D\"0\" width=3D\"152\" align=3D\"right\">=0D=0A<thead></thead>=0D=0A<tbo=\r\ndy>=0D=0A<tr style=3D\"height: 110px; background-color: #ffffff;\">=0D=0A<td =\r\nalign=3D\"left\">=0D=0A<p align=3D\"center\">&nbsp;<img src=3D\"http://www.centr=\r\nalpt.com/customer/image_gallery/358/GEORGE_NEW.jpg\" alt=3D\"\" width=3D\"110\" =\r\nheight=3D\"143\" /></p>=0D=0A</td>=0D=0A</tr>=0D=0A</tbody>=0D=0A<tfoot>=0D=\r\n=0A<tr style=3D\"height: 20px; background-color: #ffffff;\" align=3D\"left\" va=\r\nlign=3D\"top\">=0D=0A<td>=0D=0A<p style=3D\"text-align: center;\"><strong><font=\r\n color=3D\"#003366\">George Higgins Headmaster</font></strong></p>=0D=0A</td>=\r\n=0D=0A</tr>=0D=0A</tfoot>=0D=0A</table>=0D=0A<p>Parent conferences are held=\r\n as frequently as they are needed or requested. Twice during the school yea=\r\nr, parents are invited to the school to attend open-house evenings, at whic=\r\nh time they can briefly discuss their child's progress with the teachers. W=\r\nhen necessary, the headmaster or classroom teachers call parents to keep th=\r\nem informed of their child's&nbsp;performance and general behavior.</p>=0D=\r\n=0A<p>The headmaster's office is open to the students all day, everyday. St=\r\nudents feel welcome to visit the headmaster to talk, complain, laugh or ask=\r\n questions.</p>=0D=0A<p>&nbsp;</p>=0D=0A<p>&nbsp;</p>=0D=0A<h5>Faculty &amp=\r\n; Staff</h5></div></div></td></tr><tr class=3D\"r3\" id=3D\"r3_22334\"><td cols=\r\npan=3D\"2\" rowspan=3D\"1\"  width=3D\"680\"  id=3D\"c_395309\" ><table class=3D\"sh=\r\naded\"><tr><td><p><font id=3D\"r0_2233=\r\n6\"><td colspan=3D\"2\" rowspan=3D\"1\"  width=3D\"200\"  height=3D\"10\"  id=3D\"c_3=\r\n95327\" ></td></tr><tr class=3D\"r1\" id=3D\"r1_22336\"><td colspan=3D\"1\" rowspa=\r\nn=3D\"2\"  width=3D\"20\"  id=3D\"c_395328\" ></td><td colspan=3D\"1\" rowspan=3D\"1=\r\n\"  width=3D\"180\"  id=3D\"c_395331\" ><img src=3D\"http://www.centralpt.com/cus=\r\ntomer/image_gallery/358/180_gardenstudying.jpg\"></td></tr><tr class=3D\"r2\" =\r\nid=3D\"r2_22336\"><td colspan=3D\"1\" rowspan=3D\"1\"  width=3D\"180\"
